required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Milking Versus Delayed Cord Clamping in Full Term Neonates
clinical_study.official_title: Milking Versus Delayed Cord Clamping in Full Term Neonates Delivered by Elective Cesarean Section A Randomized Controlled Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Ahmed Mohamed El Kotb Abdel Fattah

brief_summary.textblock: To compare the short term risks and benefits of cord milking 5 times toward the neonate with delayed cord clamping for 120 seconds in the full term neonate delivered by cesarean section.

detailed_description.textblock:
Abstract Context: milking of the umbilical cord toward the neonate 5 times and delayed cord clamping both are good procedures to prevent anemia in neonates .
Objective: To investigate the effects of delayed umbilical cord clamping for 120 seconds, compared with milking of the cord 5 times toward the neonate on hemoglobin level after 6 weeks, Intubation,Respiratory distress,Clinical jaundice,Neonatal Intensive Care unit (NICU) admission,Apgar score (after 5 minutes of delivery).
-Maternal,Need for blood transfusion,Additional need for therapeutic uterotonics,Post postpartum hemorrhage (blood loss > 500cc),Intensive Care unit admission.
Design: Randomized controlled trial. Setting: Ain Shams university maternity hospital. Participants:300 full term infants born after a low risk pregnancy by cesarean section delivery.
Intervention: Infants were randomized to delayed umbilical cord clamping (≥120 seconds after delivery) or cord milking (5 times to ward the neonate).

primary_outcome.description: neonatal 6 weeks hemoglobin measured in gram %

secondary_outcome.description: number of infants requiring phtotherapy for jundice in the first 2 weeks
number of newborns requirng intubation in the first 2 hours after delivery
number of Neonatal Intensive Care unit (NICU) admission in the 1st 24 hours after delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal Apgar Score (After 5 Minutes of Delivery).
secondary_outcome.description: The Apgar test is done by a doctor, midwife, or nurse. The health care provider examines the baby's: Breathing effort Heart rate Muscle tone Reflexes Skin color Each category is scored with 0, 1, or 2, depending on the observed condition. The Apgar score is based on a total score of 1 to 10. The higher the score, the better the baby is doing after birth. A score of 7, 8, or 9 is normal and is a sign that the newborn is in good health. A score of 10 is very unusual, since almost all newborns lose 1 point for blue hands and feet, which is normal for after birth. Any score lower than 7 is a sign that the baby needs medical attention. The lower the score, the more help the baby needs
number of mothers with hemoglobin level < 7mg/dl and need for blood transfusion

secondary_outcome.measure: Maternal Additional Need for Therapeutic Uterotonics
secondary_outcome.description: number of mothers need for > 20 units of Oxycontin in the 1st 24 hours of delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of Third Stage of Labor
secondary_outcome.description: number of minutes from delivery of the baby till delivery of the placenta

arm_group.description: milking of the umbilical cord 5 times toward the neonate

intervention.description: milking of the cord 5 times toward the neonate
delay clamping of the cord for 120 seconds

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant females going for cesarean section that completed 37 weeks of gestation
- Medically free
Exclusion Criteria:
- Known congenital anomalies of fetus.
- Rhesus sensitization.
- Fetal hydrops.
- Medical disorder (preeclampsia - diabetes mellitus - hypertension - SLE).
- Need for urgent resuscitation.
- Multiple pregnancies.

Thane CW, Walmsley CM, Bates CJ, Prentice A, Cole TJ. Risk factors for poor iron status in British toddlers: further analysis of data from the National Diet and Nutrition Survey of children aged 1.5-4.5 years. Public Health Nutr. 2000 Dec;3(4):433-40.
Thomas DG, Grant SL, Aubuchon-Endsley NL. The role of iron in neurocognitive development. Dev Neuropsychol. 2009;34(2):196-222. doi: 10.1080/87565640802646767. Review.
van Rheenen PF, Brabin BJ. A practical approach to timing cord clamping in resource poor settings. BMJ. 2006 Nov 4;333(7575):954-8.
Yao AC, Lind J. Placental transfusion. Am J Dis Child. 1974 Jan;127(1):128-41. Review.

responsible_party.investigator_full_name: Ahmed Mohamed El Kotb Abdel Fattah

participant_flow.recruitment_details: The current RCT was conducted at Ain Shams University Maternity Hospital during the period between August 2015 to February 2016
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: No significant events following participants recruitment

outcome.title: Neonatal Apgar Score (After 5 Minutes of Delivery).
outcome.description: The Apgar test is done by a doctor, midwife, or nurse. The health care provider examines the baby's: Breathing effort Heart rate Muscle tone Reflexes Skin color Each category is scored with 0, 1, or 2, depending on the observed condition. The Apgar score is based on a total score of 1 to 10. The higher the score, the better the baby is doing after birth. A score of 7, 8, or 9 is normal and is a sign that the newborn is in good health. A score of 10 is very unusual, since almost all newborns lose 1 point for blue hands and feet, which is normal for after birth. Any score lower than 7 is a sign that the baby needs medical attention. The lower the score, the more help the baby needs

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
